node.title: Make a Spicy Gift This Holiday Season
node.description: The Mala Market’s kit for chile crisp makes enough of the fiery condiment to give your friends and family.

node.title: 19-Year-Old Allegedly Recruited Cellmate to Torture, Kill 14 People Connected to His Case
node.description: Dongwook Ko was originally charged with beating and attacking a 13-year-old while they both attended a summer violin camp.

node.title: Philadelphia to Require Proof of Vaccine or Negative COVID Test at Public Indoor Spaces
node.description: Philadelphia is not the first major U.S. city to impose such a measure in the hopes of curtailing infection rates nearly two years into the pandemic.

node.title: 'It makes me sick to drive across it': Outback creek renamed
node.description: An outback council will work with the state government to change the 'racist' name of a creek, but Indigenous elders say there are dozens more just like it across the state.

node.title: USA Gymnastics to pay Larry Nassar abuse survivors $380m
node.description: Survivors of former USA Gymnastics doctor Larry Nassar have been awarded $380 million in damages after a five-year legal battle with the governing body and the US Olympic and Paralympic Committee.

node.title: 'On again': How the $1.9b deal to buy a Pacific telco, and stop China getting it, sat in the balance
node.description: A $1.9 billion deal for taxpayers to fund Telstra to buy a key Pacific telecommunications company – to stop China getting it – may have been close to falling through, FOI documents reveal.

node.title: Kentucky tornadoes: Death toll likely to pass 100, governor says
node.description: Rescue workers are scouring debris for survivors while teams distribute water and generators to residents.

node.title: Northland Chamber boss sees red over continued restrictions
node.description: Northland Chamber of Commerce chief executive Steve Smith - who is "not a huge fan of vaccination" and is opposed to checkpoints - says the government announcement today is "a bitter pill to swallow". Audio

node.title: Northland big cat sanctuary to reopen after fatal tragedy
node.description: A Northland big cat sanctuary closed to the public for nearly eight years will roar back into life tomorrow. Audio

node.title: Recall for ham and pepperoni balloons to 2.3 million pounds
node.description: Perdue Premium Meat Co. unit initially said 232,000 pounds sold nationwide could be contaminated with listeria.

node.title: U.S. woman to face U.K. court over teenager's death
node.description: Sacoolas is accused of killing 19-year-old Harry Dunn in a collision outside an air base in eastern England used by U.S. forces in 2019.

node.title: "Dash for Cash" stunt demeans teachers, critics say
node.description: Mortgage lender and hockey team draw fire for promotion in which teachers raced to collect money for classroom supplies.

node.title: Supreme Court allows New York vaccine mandate for health care workers
node.description: Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch dissented.

node.title: Say It With Ice Cream
node.description: A new 12 Days of Ice Cream package from eCreamery in Omaha offers a dozen pints for the holidays.

node.title: Hot Bread Kitchen Offers Uncommon Holiday Gifts
node.description: Branded sweatshirts and totes benefiting the nonprofit are among the presents available this year.

node.title: New York City businesses reacts to new state masks-or-vaccinations rules: ‘Most people, they understand.’
node.description: The mandate, which requires businesses to ask customers for proof of full vaccination or enforce mask-wearing, comes as the state grapples with the threat of a winter surge in coronavirus cases.

node.title: Supreme Court Allows Vaccine Mandate for New York Healthcare Workers
node.description: Doctors and nurses challenged a state coronavirus vaccine requirement that had medical but not religious exemptions, saying it violated their right to free exercise of their faiths.

node.title: Denmark and Norway Predict Drastic Spike in Omicron Cases
node.description: Health authorities in Europe are warning of a sharp increase in Omicron cases, adding to an existing surge from the Delta variant.

node.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Almost 800,000 U.S. Covid Deaths
node.description: People 65 and older are the most vulnerable.

node.title: Russia, India Veto U.N. Resolution on Climate-Related Security Dangers
node.description: Russia and India voted against a U.N. measure led by Ireland and Niger that would have named climate change as an international security threat.

node.title: Trump-Appointed Judge Won't Dismiss Obstruction Charges Against Accused Capitol Rioters
node.description: Judge Dabney Friedrich kept obstruction charges for two accused rioters because it covers a broader set of actions allegedly done by the defendants.

node.title: Nearly Half of Holiday Shoppers Aware of Smash-and-Grab Uptick Feel 'Less Safe': Poll
node.description: About 1 in 5 individuals in the entire survey group told pollsters they did not intend to shop in person at all.

node.title: All of today's coronavirus news in the one spot
node.description: Get up to speed with all of the coronavirus news from across Australia in our live COVID blog. Follow live.

node.title: Education Is Like a Beautiful Garden
node.description: Consider giving to education-related charities this holiday season.

node.title: Verstappen wins first F1 title with last lap overtake
node.description: Red Bull's Max Verstappen took his first Formula One title, denying rival Lewis Hamilton a record eighth, with a last lap overtake to win a season-ending Abu Dhabi Grand Prix that started and ended in…

node.title: White House adds two key coordinators to implement infrastructure law
node.description: An Amazon executive and a top official at Center for American Progress have been appointed to coordinate the implementation of the new infrastructure law.

node.title: Suzette Winter, Who Documented Hollywood’s Golden Age, Dies at 90
node.description: She and her husband produced more than 30 rosy biographical films for television about the era’s biggest stars.

node.title: Derek Chauvin Appears Likely to Plead Guilty to Federal Crimes
node.description: A change of plea hearing has been set for Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer who was found guilty of murdering George Floyd in April.

node.title: More than 50 million total coronavirus cases have been found in the U.S.
node.description: It is almost certainly a substantial undercount, since many infected people have no symptoms or mistake them for those of another illness, and not everyone gets tested.

node.title: E.U. Debates How to Coordinate With U.S., U.K. If Russia Invades Western-Leaning Ukraine
node.description: According to U.S. intelligence officials, Russia moved 70,000 troops close to Ukraine's border and is readying for a potential invasion early next year.
